Show also that if (xn)n\left(x_{n}\right)_{n}(xn​)n​ is a Cauchy sequence in XXX, and fff is uniformly continuous, then the sequence (f(xn))n\left(f\left(x_{n}\right)\right)_{n}(f(xn​))n​ is convergent.

    (b) Let f:X→Rf: X \rightarrow \mathbb{R}f:X→R be continuous, and XXX be sequentially compact. Show that fff is uniformly continuous. Is fff necessarily Lipschitz? Justify your answer.

    (c) Let YYY be a dense subset of XXX, and let g:Y→Rg: Y \rightarrow \mathbb{R}g:Y→R be a continuous function. Show that there exists at most one continuous function f:X→Rf: X \rightarrow \mathbb{R}f:X→R such that for all y∈Yy \in Yy∈Y, f(y)=g(y)f(y)=g(y)f(y)=g(y).   • Paper 1, Section II, D

    Electromagnetism
    Part IB, 2016

    (a) From the differential form of Maxwell's equations with J=0,B=0\mathbf{J}=\mathbf{0}, \mathbf{B}=\mathbf{0}J=0,B=0 and a time-independent electric field, derive the integral form of Gauss's law.

    (b) Derive an expression for the electric field E\mathbf{E}E around an infinitely long line charge lying along the zzz-axis with charge per unit length μ\muμ. Find the electrostatic potential ϕ\phiϕ up to an arbitrary constant.

    (c) Now consider the line charge with an ideal earthed conductor filling the region x>dx>dx>d. State the boundary conditions satisfied by ϕ\phiϕ and E\mathbf{E}E on the surface of the conductor.

    [You may assume that the operators x^\hat{x}x^ and p^\hat{p}p^​ are Hermitian.]
